title: Protocol for analyzing the biosynthesis and degradation of N-glycan precursors in mammalian cells
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Cell counting
Timing: 30 min
Protocol for cell counting to normalize the amounts of DLOs, POSs, and nucleotide sugars.
Note: Cell counting should be performed at which cells are harvested for preparation of DLOs, POSs, and nucleotide sugars.
Aspirate culture medium from a ϕ100 mm culture dish.
Wash the cells once with 5 mL of D-PBS (-).
Note: D-PBS (-) should not contain calcium chloride or magnesium chloride, since these inorganic salts inhibit the action of trypsin.
Add 1 mL of 0.05% (w/v) trypsin-0.53 mM EDTA to dish.
Incubate cells for 1–2 min at 37°C in a CO2 incubator.
Tap the lateral side of the dish to detach cells.
Add 9 mL of the complete medium.
Pipette up and down to dissociate cells.
Transfer the cell suspension to a fresh 15-mL centrifuge tube.
Mix 10 μL of the cell suspension and 10 μL of 0.4% (w/v) trypan blue dye in a 1.5-mL centrifuge tube.
Count the live and dead cells using a hemocytometer.
Critical: Since necrotic cells are no longer metabolically active, these cells should be minimized in the cell preparation in order to obtain reliable results. For reference, we use cell cultures for the extraction of DLOs, POSs, and nucleotide sugars only when the number of trypan blue-positive necrotic cells is less than 10% of the total cell numbers.
Preparation of cell homogenates for extraction of DLOs and POSs
Timing: 4 h
This protocol allows for the separation of adherent mammalian cells into ethanol-insoluble fraction, which contains DLOs, and ethanol-soluble fraction, which contains POSs (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]). Handling time should be minimized (as short as possible), because of the relatively labile nature of DLOs and POSs.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/451-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. A schematic diagram showing the preparation of cell homogenates for extraction of DLOs and POSs

Aspirate the culture medium from a ϕ100 mm culture dish.
Wash the cells two times with 5 mL each of 1× PBS that was warmed up at 25°C.
Aspirate the residual PBS completely.
Place the dish on ice.
Remove the cell lysis solution (70% [v/v] ethanol) from a freezer or a dry ice-ethanol bath, and immediately add 2 mL of the lysis solution to the dish.
Scrape cells with a scraper on ice and transfer the homogenate into a fresh 15-mL centrifuge tube by pipetting.
Note: The end of the tips may be cut with clean scissors, as cells form large aggregates upon scraping in 70% ethanol.
Repeat steps 15 and 16 one more time to maximize yields.
Vortex the homogenate (∼ 4 mL) for 10 s and incubate for 15 min at 0°C.
Critical: This incubation time should be accurate.
Centrifuge the homogenate at 10,000 × g for 10 min at 4°C.
Transfer the supernatant (∼ 4 mL) to a fresh 15-mL centrifuge tube by pipetting.
Note: The supernatant contains POSs.
Keep the remaining cell pellet for the extraction of DLOs (see next section).
Evaporate the supernatant to dryness using a Speed-Vac or under a nitrogen stream.
Note: The temperature of the centrifugal part of the Speed-Vac should be set to “Ambient.”
Pause Point: Pellets and dried samples can be stored at −20°C for at least 1 week.
Preparation of DLOs
Timing: 12 h
Protocol for the extraction and mild acid hydrolysis of DLOs, followed by desalting of the released free glycans (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/451-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Preparation of DLOs
(A) A schematic diagram showing the extraction of DLOs and liberation of the glycan moiety (free glycans).

(B) A simplified protocol for DLO extraction (steps 1–4), mild acid hydrolysis of DLOs and desalting of the resulting free glycans (step 5).
Extraction of DLOs (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B, steps 1–4).
Critical: All centrifugation steps must be performed at 25°C.
Critical: A swing rotor must be used for all centrifugation steps.
Critical: Do not chill the organic solvents for DLO extraction. Keep them at 25°C.
Add 2 mL of methanol to the cell pellets that were prepared at step 21.
Vortex vigorously until the cell pellets become uniformly dispersed.
Note: A probe sonicator can be used to disperse cell pellets in methanol if the pellet forms hard aggregates and are difficult to disperse.
Centrifuge at 1,800 × g for 5 min at 25°C.
Discard the supernatant by decantation.
Repeat steps a–d one more time.
Add 2 mL of chloroform/methanol (C/M; 2:1, v/v) to the pellets.
Vortex vigorously until the cell pellets become uniformly dispersed.
Centrifuge at 1,800 × g for 5 min at 25°C.
Discard the supernatant by decantation.
Repeat steps f–i one more time.
Dry the pellets under a nitrogen stream.
Critical: It is critical to remove as much of the chloroform as possible, because chloroform, if much remains in the samples, it interferes with the extraction of DLOs in the next step. However, do not overdry the samples, as the pellets will become fluffy and can blow away.
Add 2 mL of 4 mM MgCl2 in methanol/water (M/W; 1:1, v/v) to the pellet.
Critical: MgCl2 in this solution is essential to extract DLOs from the pellet.
Vortex vigorously until the cell pellet becomes uniformly dispersed.
Centrifuge at 1,800 × g for 5 min at 25°C.
Discard the supernatant completely by decantation.

Critical: It is critical to remove the solution as much as possible. If much remains, it results in the separation of an aqueous-organic solvent phase in the next step.
Repeat steps l–o one more time.
Add 2 mL of chloroform/methanol/water (C/M/W; 10:10:3, v/v/v) to the pellet.
Vortex vigorously until the cell pellets become uniformly dispersed.
Close the cap of tubes and incubate them for 10 min at 37°C.
Centrifuge at 1,800 × g for 5 min at 25°C.
Transfer the supernatant to a fresh 9-mL glass test tube with a screw cap by using a glass Pasteur pipette with a nipple.
Critical: Caution: the supernatant contains the extracted DLOs.
Repeat steps q–t for the remaining pellets one more time.
Transfer the second supernatant to the glass tube that contains the first supernatant.
Pause Point: The combined supernatant can be stored at −20°C for at least 1 week.
Evaporate the combined supernatant to dryness using a Speed-Vac or under a nitrogen stream.
Note: The temperature of the centrifugal part of the Speed-Vac should be set to “Ambient.”
Pause Point: The dried DLO pellets can be stored at −20°C at least for 1 week.
Mild acid hydrolysis of DLOs (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B, step 5).
Add 1 mL of 20 mM HCl in 50% (v/v) 2-propanol to the dried DLO pellets.
Close the cap, briefly vortex, and allow the tubes to stand on a metal rack.
Heat the tubes for 30 min at 100°C in an oven.
Alternatives: A heat block can also be used.
Chill the tubes in a rack by immersing them into ice-water bath for 3 min.
Critical: Caution: tubes and racks are extremely hot. Wear appropriate gloves.
Evaporate the hydrolysates to dryness using a Speed-Vac or under a nitrogen stream.

Note: The temperature of the centrifugal part of the Speed-Vac should be set to “Ambient.”
Critical: Caution: after evaporating HCl, the Speed-Vac should be washed by evaporating 100 mL of water.
Add 1 mL of Milli-Q water to the dried pellets.
Resuspend the released oligosaccharides by vigorous vortexing for 10 s.
Centrifuge the tubes at 1,800 × g for 5 min at 25°C.
Transfer the supernatant to a fresh 15-mL centrifuge tube.
Note: The supernatant contains the released oligosaccharides.
Repeat steps f–h one more time.
Transfer the second supernatant to the tube that contains the first supernatant.
Desalting of the released free glycans (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B, step 5).
Set fresh 15-mL centrifuge tubes on a tube rack (1 tube/each sample).
Place an InertSep GC column (1 column/each sample) in the 15-mL centrifuge tube.
Add 2.5 mL of 100% acetonitrile to the top of the column.
Note: Activation step.
Let the solution pass through the column and discard the eluate.
Add 2.5 mL of Milli-Q water to the top of the column.
Note: Wash step.
Let the solution pass through the column and discard the eluate.
Repeat steps e and f one more time.
Add the combined supernatant (approximately 2 mL) obtained in step 24k to the top of the activated InertSep GC column.
Note: Binding step.
Let the sample completely enter the column and discard the eluate.
Add 2.5 mL of Milli-Q water to the top of the column.
Note: Wash step.
Let water pass through the column and discard the eluate.
Repeat steps j and k one more time.
Place fresh 15-mL centrifuge tubes to a tube rack.
Wipe the outside of the InertSep GC columns with clean KimWipes and place the columns in fresh 15-mL centrifuge tubes.

Add 2.5 mL of 25% (v/v) acetonitrile to the top of the column.
Note: Elution step.
Collect the eluate (2.5 mL).
Note: The eluate contains free glycans released from DLOs.
Pause Point: The samples can be stored at −20°C for at least 1 week.
Concentrate the eluate obtained in step p to ∼0.5 mL using a Speed-Vac or under nitrogen stream.
Note: The temperature of the centrifugal part of the Speed-Vac should be set to “Ambient.” If the eluate is completely dried, add 500 μL of water, vortex, spin down, and proceed to step s.
Vortex for 10 s and spin down.
Transfer the solution to a fresh 1.5-mL centrifuge tube.
Dry the solution completely using a Speed-Vac or under a nitrogen stream.
Note: The temperature of the centrifugal part of the Speed-Vac should be set to “Ambient.”
Pause Point: The dried pellets can be stored at −20°C for at least 1 week.
Critical: Residual water increases the epimerization of the innermost GlcNAc to ManNAc of free glycans during the fluorescent labeling with PA.
Preparation of POSs
Timing: 1 day
Protocol for separation of POSs from neutral free glycans, dephosphorylation of POSs, and desalting of the dephosphorylated free glycans (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/451-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Preparation of POSs
(A) A schematic diagram showing the purification of POSs and liberation of the glycan moiety (free glycans).
(B) A simplified protocol for size-exclusion chromatography (step 1), anion-exchange chromatography (step 2), dephosphorylation of POSs, and desalting of the resulting free glycans (step 3). SEC, size-exclusion chromatography; AP, alkaline phosphatase.
Equilibration of size-exclusion columns (SEC, 1 column for each sample).
Open the top lid of the PD MidiTrap G-25 column, discard the storage buffer, and remove the bottom cap.
Stand the columns on the attached rack and place a waste container below the columns.

Fill the top space of the column with Milli-Q water.
Let the water pass through the column.
Repeat steps c and d two more times.
Cap the bottom end of the column and close the top lid until use.
Note: Equilibrate the column just before use.
Equilibration of Sep-Pak Accell Plus QMA cartridge (1 cartridge for each sample).
Remove the piston from a 5-mL syringe.
Connect the outlet of the syringe to the inlet of a QMA cartridge.
Add 5 mL of 10 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.4) to the syringe.
Place a piston and push it to elute buffer at a rate of approximately 2 drops/s.
Dry the cartridge by blowing out air from a syringe.
Disconnect the syringe and remove the piston.
Connect the syringe outlet to the cartridge and store at room temperature until use.
Note: Equilibrate the cartridge just before use.
Add 1.0 mL of Milli-Q water to the dried cell extract obtained in step 22 (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B, step 1).
Vortex vigorously until the pellet is completely dispersed.
Transfer the suspension to a fresh 1.5-mL centrifugation tube.
Centrifuge at 15,000 × g for 3 min at 25°C.
Desalting by size-exclusion chromatography (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B, step 1).
Add the supernatant (exactly 1 mL) to the top of PD MidiTrap G-25 columns that have been equilibrated with water (see step 26).
Note: Make sure that water is completely removed from top space of the column before adding the sample.
Let the sample enter into the column and discard the eluate.
Place a 2.0-mL centrifuge tube just beneath the column outlet.
Add 1.5 mL of water to the top of the column.
Collect the eluate (1.5 mL).
Note: This eluate contains POSs.
Add 15 μL of 1 M Tris-HCl (pH 7.4) to the eluate and mix thoroughly (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B, step 2).

Anion-exchange chromatography (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B, step 2).
Note: The objective of this step is to separate the POSs from other neutral materials (e.g., neutral free glycans).
Add the eluate (1.5 mL) to the syringe that was connected to Sep-Pak Accell Plus QMA cartridge (see step 27).
Note: Binding step of POSs.
Place a piston and push at a rate of approximately 2 drops/s.
Discard the flow-through.
Dry the cartridge by blowing out air from a syringe.
Disconnect the syringe from QMA cartridge and remove the piston.
Connect the same syringe to the QMA cartridge.
Add 5 mL of 10 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.4) to the syringe.
Note: Wash step.
Place a piston and push at a rate of approximately 2 drops/s.
Discard the flow-through.
Dry the cartridge by blowing out air from a syringe.
Disconnect the syringe from QMA cartridge and remove the piston.
Repeat steps from g to k one more time.
Connect a fresh 5-mL syringe without a piston to the QMA cartridge.
Stand fresh 15-mL centrifuge tubes in a rack.
Add 5 mL of 10 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.4) containing 70 mM NaCl to the syringe.
Note: Elution step.
Place a piston and push at a rate of approximately 2 drops/s.
Collect the eluate in a 15-mL centrifuge tube.
Mix the eluate by vortexing and spin down.
Pause Point: The samples can be stored at −20°C for at least 2–3 days.
Dephosphorylation of POSs (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B, step 3).
Divide the eluate (5 mL) obtained in step 34r equally to two portions (2.5 mL each).
Add 5 μL of rAPid alkaline phosphatase to one half and mix thoroughly. The other half is left untreated with phosphatase. Spin both down.
Incubate the samples with or without phosphatase for 16 h at 37°C.

Pause Point: The reaction mixtures can be stored at −20°C for at least 2–3 days.
Desalting of dephosphorylated free glycans (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B, step 3).
Set fresh 15-mL centrifuge tubes on a tube rack (1 tube/each sample).
Place an InertSep GC column (1 column/each sample) in the 15-mL centrifuge tube.
Add 2.5 mL of 100% acetonitrile to the top space of the column.
Note: Activation step.
Let the solution pass through the column and discard the eluate.
Add 2.5 mL of Milli-Q water to the top space of the column.
Note: Wash step.
Let the solution pass through the column and discard the eluate.
Repeat steps e and f one more time.
Add the reaction mixtures (2.5 mL) obtained in step 35c to the activated InertSep GC column.
Note: Binding step.
Let the samples enter the column and discard the eluate.
Add 2.5 mL of Milli-Q water to the top space of the column.
Note: Wash step.
Let the solution pass through the column and discard the eluate.
Repeat steps j and k one more time.
Place fresh 15-mL centrifuge tubes in a tube rack.
Wipe the outside of InertSep GC columns with clean KimWipes and place the columns into fresh 15-mL centrifuge tubes.
Add 2.5 mL of 25% (v/v) acetonitrile to the top space of the column.
Note: Elution step.
Collect the eluate (2.5 mL).
Note: Only dephosphorylated POSs (free glycans) are eluted from the column at this step. POSs are retained in the column.
Pause Point: The samples can be stored at −20°C for at least 1 week.
Concentrate the eluate obtained at step 36p to ∼0.5 mL by using Speed-Vac or under nitrogen stream.

Note: The temperature of the centrifugal part of the Speed-Vac should be set to “Ambient.” If the eluate is completely dried, add 500 μL of water, vortex, spin down, and proceed to step s.
Vortex well and spin down.
Transfer the solution to a fresh 1.5-mL centrifuge tube.
Dry the solution completely by using Speed-Vac or under a nitrogen stream.
Note: The temperature of the centrifugal part of the Speed-Vac should be set to “Ambient.”
Pause Point: The dried samples can be stored at −20°C for at least 1 week.
Critical: Residual water increases epimerization of innermost GlcNAc to ManNAc of free glycans during the fluorescent labeling with PA.
Fluorescent labeling of glycans with PA
Timing: 2 h for labeling and 30 min for purification
The protocol for the fluorescent labeling of free glycans with PA and purification of the PA-labeled glycans (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/451-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Fluorescent labeling of free glycans and the HPLC analysis
(A) A simplified protocol for the fluorescent labeling of free glycans with 2-aminopyridine (PA) (step 1) and purification of the PA-labeled glycans (step 2).
(B) HPLC setting for analysis of PA-labeled glycans. DAB, dimethylamine-borane complex.
PA labeling (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]A, step 1).
Dissolve the PA in the solution by heating at 80°C.
Vortex and spin down.
Immediately pipette out 20 μL of PA solution and add it to the dried free glycan preparations obtained in steps 25t (DLOs) or 36t (POSs).
Critical: Caution: PA solution is easily solidified.
Vortex for 10 s and spin down.
Incubate for 1 h at 80°C in the dark.
Note: Use a heat block covered with aluminum foil.
Add 20 μL of the dimethylamine-borane complex solution to the reaction mixture.
Note: Prepare the dimethylamine-borane complex solution just before use.
Critical: Caution: discard the solution immediately after use.

Mix the reaction mixture thoroughly by vortexing and spin down.
Incubate for 1 h at 80°C in the dark.
Pause Point: The reaction mixture can be stored at −20°C for 2–3 days.
Add 960 μL of acetonitrile to the reaction mixture.
Mix the reaction mixture thoroughly by vortexing and spin down.
Activation of MonoFas spin columns.
Add 200 μL of Milli-Q water to the MonoFas spin column.
Centrifuge at 10,000 × g for 30 s and discard the eluate.
Add 700 μL of 100% acetonitrile to the spin column.
Centrifuge at 10,000 × g for 30 s and discard the eluate.
Repeat c and d one more time.
Purification of PA-labeled glycans (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]A, step 2).
Add 700 μL of a PA labeling reaction mixture to the activated MonoFas spin column.
Centrifuge at 10,000 × g for 30 s and discard the eluate.
Add the remaining PA labeling reaction mixture to the same spin column.
Centrifuge at 10,000 × g for 30 s and discard the eluate.
Add 700 μL of 95% (v/v) acetonitrile to the spin column.
Centrifuge at 10,000 × g for 30 s and discard the eluate.
Repeat steps e and f one more time.
Centrifuge at 10,000 × g for 30 s to remove the remaining acetonitrile solution.
Remove the spin column from tube and place onto a fresh 1.5-mL centrifuge tube.
Add 100 μL of Milli-Q water to the spin column.
Centrifuge at 10,000 × g for 30 s.
Repeat steps j and k one more time in the same tube.
Note: The combined eluates (∼200 μL) contain PA-labeled glycans. The eluate can be concentrated using a Speed-Vac.
Pause Point: The combined eluates can be stored at −20°C for several month to several years.
Size-fractionation HPLC analysis of PA-labeled glycans

Timing: 2 h for equilibration and 1 additional h per sample
Protocol for separation and quantification of PA-labeled glycans by size-fractionation HPLC (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]B).
Start the HPLC system, connect Shodex NH2P-50 4E column, and set the gradient program (see the Materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment] section “HPLC settings for the detection of PA-labeled glycans”).
Equilibrate the column for 20 min by running a mixed eluent (97% HPLC eluent A and 3% HPLC eluent B; see the Materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment] section for recipes of these HPLC eluents).
Add 10 μL of samples to the bottom of snap vials.
Critical: Take great care not to leave any air between sample solution and the bottom of vials.
Seal the vial with a snap cap.
Set the vial to the auto-sampler.
Analyze the samples in the sequence in the following order: Milli-Q water (10 μL), standard PA-labeled glycans with known concentrations (e.g., PA-glucose oligomers; 2 pmol as PA-labeled glucose hexamer), and your PA-labeled glycan samples.
Note: Standard PA-labeled glycans are used as an external standard to standardize the elution positions and to quantitate the PA-labeled glycans in the samples.
Note: Collect peaks from the waste line of the HPLC if PA-labeled glycans are further analyzed by matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization (MALDI)-time-of-flight (TOF)-mass (MS) analysis.
To shut down HPLC, replace the HPLC lines with 20% (v/v) acetonitrile.
Wash the HPLC column with the storage solvent (20% (v/v) acetonitrile) for 20 min at a flow rate of 0.8 mL/min.
Disconnect the HPLC column, cap both ends, and store at room temperature.
Connect the outlet of the injector and the inlet of the detector with a plug to prevent the HPLC lines from drying out.
Preparation of cellular nucleotide sugars
Timing: 2 h for the preparation of cell homogenates and 6 h for the purification of nucleotide sugars

Protocol for the preparation of cell homogenates and purification of nucleotide sugars (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/451-Fig6.jpg
Figure 6. Preparation and LS-ESI-MS analysis of cellular nucleotide sugars
(A) A simplified scheme for cell lysis (step 1) and the purification of nucleotide sugars (step 2).
(B) HPLC and ESI-MS setting for nucleotide sugar analysis.
Critical: Due to the relatively labile nature of nucleotide sugars, it is important to perform the extraction rapidly. In particular, the centrifugation step should be avoided when collecting cell pellets.
Preparation of cell homogenates (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]A, step 1).
Culture the cells in ϕ100 mm dishes (see the “Cell culture[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.1]” of the “Before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]”).
Wash the cells once with 5 mL of ice-cold PBS.
Aspirate the residual PBS completely.
Add 500 μL of ice-cold 70% (v/v) ethanol to the dish.
Alternatives: The dish may be placed on dry ice.
Scrape the cells and pipette in and out three times to disperse cell aggregates.
Transfer the cell suspension (∼500 μL) into a fresh 1.5-mL centrifuge tube.
Homogenize the cell suspension using a Bioruptor for 5 min at 0°C.
Alternatives: The cell suspension may be homogenized by using the Handy Sonic Disruptor for 1 min on ice.
Add 5 μL of unnatural 0.5 mM GDP-Glc (2.5 nmol) to the cell suspension.
Note: GDP-Glc is added to the samples as an internal standard to calculate yields of the preparation.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 16,000 × g for 15 min at 4°C.
Transfer the supernatant to a 1.5-mL centrifuge tube.
Freeze the supernatant at −20°C and evaporate by using a Speed-Vac concentrator.
Note: The temperature of the centrifugal part of the Speed-Vac should be set to “Ambient.”
Pause Point: Dried cellular extracts can be stored at −20°C for several months.
Purification of nucleotide sugars (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]A, step 2).

Activate ENVI-Carb columns by adding 2 mL of 80% (v/v) acetonitrile in 0.1% (v/v) TFA.
Critical: Caution: do not allow the ENVI-Carb columns to dry out after this activation step.
Wash the column with 1 mL of distilled water.
Dissolve the freeze-dried samples in 1 mL of 10 mM NH4HCO3.
Apply the sample (1 mL) to the activated ENVI-Carb column.
Sequentially wash the column once with 1 mL of water, 1 mL of 25% (v/v) acetonitrile, 200 μL of water, and 1 mL of 50 mM triethylamine acetate buffer (pH 7.0).
Alternatives: Use the Pressure+ vacuum to speed up these elution processes.
Elute the nucleotide sugars from the column with 1 mL of 25% (v/v) acetonitrile in 50 mM triethylamine acetate buffer (pH 7.0).
Evaporate the eluates to dryness using a Speed-Vac concentrator.
Pause Point: Dried nucleotide sugars can be stored at −20°C for several months.
Ion-pair reversed-phase LC ESI-MS for simultaneous quantification of nucleotide sugars
Timing: 1 day
Protocol for the separation, identification and quantification of nucleotide sugars by ion-pair reversed-phase LC ESI-MS/MS (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]B).
Set the MS conditions as described in the “Before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]” section under “Mass spectrometer settings[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.6].”
Program the m/z values for precursor ions and product ions.
For the quantification of each nucleotide sugar, first run authentic standard mixtures containing 10 pmol/each, and confirm that they produce a robust peak on the LC-MS system.
Prepare the calibration curve on the same run on the day as an LC/MS run, to quantify nucleotide sugars. Analyze the diluted authentic standards at the following concentrations: 0.01, 0.025, 0.05, 0.1, 0.25, 0.5, 1, 2.5, 5, 10, 25, and 50 μM.
Dissolve the extracted nucleotide sugars in distilled water (50 μL), and apply aliquots (10 μL) for LC-MS analysis.

Extract the peak areas of nucleotide sugars in the extraction ion chromatograms.
Optional: Alternative Ion-pair reversed-phase conventional HPLC
UDP-GalNAc and UDP-GlcNAc were co-eluted in the LC-MS analysis. To quantify of those, it is recommended to use a conventional HPLC system without MS as follows.
The method for simultaneous determination of nucleotide sugars using conventional HPLC coupled with UV detection has been previously reported (Nakajima et al., 2010[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9]). The use of a non-volatile tetrabutylammonium hydrogen sulfate is crucial for complete separation, however the ion-pair reagent is incompatible with MS detection.
